dt.t: The soot on the lampshade {it}obscured{/it} the light.

dt: {bc}to {d_link|conceal|conceal} or hide by or as if by covering

dt.t: … snow on glaciers can {wi}obscure{/wi} deep crevasses.

quotes.t: It was eight o'clock when we landed; we walked for a short time on the shore enjoying the transitory light, and then retired to the inn and contemplated the lovely scene of waters, woods, and mountains, {qword}obscured{/qword} in darkness, yet still displaying their black outlines.
But evening comes or even noon and some combination of nervous tensions {qword}obscures{/qword} my memories of what whiskey costs me in the way of physical and intellectual well-being.
Throughout this book, the ground of fact becomes {qword}obscured{/qword} entirely by a deep layer of speculative quicksand.

… [Mr. Schuller's] … "Early Jazz" brought a sometimes Olympian precision to writing about an art that has often languished in the whale's belly of sociology, {qword}obscured{/qword} by pretension and blubbery thinking.

et: Middle English {it}obscuren,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}obscurer, oscurir,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}obscūrāre{/it} "to darken, eclipse, dim, conceal from knowledge, make difficult to comprehend," verbal derivative of {it}obscūrus{/it} "dim, dark, imperfectly known, concealed from knowledge, incomprehensible" {ma}{mat|obscure:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to make dark, dim, or indistinct
to conceal or hide by or as if by covering
to reduce (a vowel) to the value \ə\
